ipusheveryoneaway 160977028029 "2017-05-23 06:50:15 GMT" http://ipusheveryoneaway.tumblr.com/post/160977028029/jaysecretwords-avete-presente-leffetto "jaysecretwords: Avete presente l'effetto Farfalla? È una teoria scientifica ed essa spiega che il battito delle ali di una farfalla in una qualche parte del mondo è in grado di scatenare un uragano da un'altra parte del mondo. Per farla breve un gesto
column3: scatena una serie di eventi che possono arrivare a creare un grave danno. È così vero. Pensate alle parole che diciamo ogni giorno: Ne basta una detta nel modo sbagliato
column5: per essere fraintesa o rigirata e magari tramandata ad altre persone che a loro volta fraintendono o esagerano. Alla fine una frase che in apparenza era solo una frase potrebbe ferire qualcuno in modo profondo. Oppure pensiamo ai gesti: Basta un gesto fatto senza pensare a poter provocare effetti non belli alle persone che ci circondano. Non vi fa paura questo? A me sì. Ma ho capito che l'effetto Farfalla vale anche per le cose belle. Se dico una parola dolce
column7: se dono amore sia nelle parole che nei gesti allora i piccoli eventi che nasceranno da quel che dico o faccio scateneranno un qualcosa di positivo. Magari invece di ferirla una persona la si fa sorridere. Magari invece di creare un danno a qualcuno ci ritroviamo per salvarlo. Non vi fa sentire bene questo? A me sì. Tutti noi possiamo essere vittime o carnefici dell'effetto farfalla ma se usassimo questa teoria per il bene l'uragano non avverrebbe. Non battiamo le ali
column8: piuttosto fermiamoci un secondo a pensare alle conseguenze." False text

column1: ipusheveryoneaway 160976820136 "2017-05-23 06:40:13 GMT" http://ipusheveryoneaway.tumblr.com/post/160976820136/jaysecretwords-non-è-ironico-che-di-fronte-un "jaysecretwords: Non è ironico che di fronte un insulto
column3: non fatichiamo a liberare la lingua ma di fronte il momento di parlar d'amore la stessa lingua si blocca e non esce nulla? Nel mandare a quel paese qualcuno reagiamo quasi d'istinto mentre nel dire ti amo soffochiamo tutto per paura di sbagliare. Sbagliamo nell'amare o nell'odiare? La risposta è semplice ma i fatti parlano d'altro. Sappiamo di sbagliare nel mostrare odio
column4: sappiamo che amare è giusto e che sconfigge il suo opposto ma nonostante ciò abbiamo paura del secondo e dimostriamo facilmente il primo anche nelle piccole cose. Non vi spaventa questo? Non vi fa paura la facilità con la quale giudichiamo e la difficoltà con la quale rispettiamo? Non vi fa paura la facilità con la quale alziamo la voce e la difficoltà nel tenerla bassa per sussurrare dolci cose? Ci imbarazza
column7: ci imbarazza e sapete una cosa? Facciamo bene a sentirci in imbarazzo poiché chi odia
column8: in modo quasi naturale tra l'altro
column9: di fronte l'amore non può sentire altro che imbarazzo." False text

column1: ipusheveryoneaway 91525188260 "2014-07-12 05:50:51 GMT" http://ipusheveryoneaway.tumblr.com/post/91525188260/my-parents-are-dead-and-my-sister-is-disabled "congalineofdurin:  cockismybusiness:  team—wolverine:  therealbarbielifts:  eisforedna:  On May 28th
column4: turned 31.   Her mental age is about three years old. She loves Winnie the Pooh
column6: and Sesame Street. Even though the below picture is unconvincing.   Edna and “Cookie.” I think she was trying to play it cool.  My name is Jeanie. I’m Edna’s younger sister. I’m also her guardian and caregiver.   That’s me on the left. (Hey
column7: you never know. After a year of writing a blog about online dating - Jeanie Does the Internet - I’ve come to learn that there are A LOT of fools on the internet.)   ANYWAY
column8: I’m not “doing the internet” anymore. I’m taking care of Edna full-time
column9: after completing my MFA in Writing for Screen & Television at USC.  May 16
column10: 2014. I wanted a picture. Edna wanted breakfast. In case you’re wondering where our parents are
column11: they’re dead. Our mom died of breast cancer when she was just 33.   Us with mom before she died. (Obviously.) As for our dad
column12: he peaced-out around the time my mom got sick. His loss - we’re awesome.   Here we are being awesome at the beach. Pushing a wheelchair in the sand? Not so awesome.  In case you’re wondering “What’s wrong?” with my sister - as a stranger once asked me on the street  -  NOTHING. Yes
column13: Edna has a rare form of epilepsy - Lennox-Gastaut syndrome - but I don’t know if that’s anymore “wrong” than people who don’t have manners.  Basically
column15: ” and started having seizures as a baby. They eventually got so bad that they cut off the oxygen to her brain
column16: causing her to be mentally disabled. Or impaired. Or intellectually disabled. Or whatever you want to call it - except “retarded
column18: President Obama signed Rosa’s Law into effect
column19: replacing that word with “intellectually impaired.”  Which is cool and all
column20: but services for the disabled and the people who care for them are SEVERELY LACKING. Also
column21: there’s a bunch of people working in taxpayer-funded positions who are supposed to help families like us
column23: I know.) They just fill out paperwork (whenever they feel like it) with asinine statements like this:   YUP. I transport my sister down the stairs in her wheelchair
column24: because that is not only safe
column25: but TOTALLY PRACTICAL. Why doesn’t everyone in a wheelchair just take the stairs
column26: for God’s sake? Stop being so lazy
column29: Edna’s legs do work. Whether or not she wants them to
column30: is another story.   Edna refusing to go inside.  These are the stairs that I have to carry her up - by myself - on a daily basis. That is
column31: until one of my legs break and both of us are just sitting at the bottom of the stairs
column33: I have begged - BEGGED - the State of California to help my sister
column34: which they are required by law - The Lanterman Act specifically - to do so. But they’ve told me “these things take time” and that I “need to amend my expectations.” (That was said to me when I refused to place Edna at AN ALL-MALE CARE FACILITY. Because yes
column35: that was an “option” that was offered to me.)  Prior to Edna moving in with me in my one-bedroom apartment
column36: she was living with her amazing caregiver
column39: where we went to high school and I did my undergrad. Edna’s reppin’ the Wildcats below.   But back in November
column40: Gaby also died from breast cancer. (FUCK YOU
column41: BREAST CANCER!) This picture was taken a month before she died. She never even told me she was sick because she didn’t want me to worry.  By the way
column42: we were raised by our grandma. Edna and her were very close.  She’s dead
column43: too. Surprise. She died when I was 20 and Edna was 21. That’s when I became Edna’s legal guardian and Gaby stepped into the picture to help me out with Edna.  So
column47: where I tried to get the folks over at The Frank D. Lanterman Regional Center to help me. I’ve told them I’m worried about our safety - that one of us could get hurt on the stairs -  I’ve told them I can’t afford to pay the private babysitters $15/hour because the ones social services sent me who make $9/hour were unreliable (they didn’t show up on time or at all so I could get to school and work)
column48: untrustworthy (one of them let Edna go to the bathroom in the kitchen and then took her into the bathroom because “that what I thought I was supposed to do.”)  But the people over at the FLRC don’t return my calls
column49: they don’t file the paperwork on time - and the first caseworker that was assigned to us actually LAUGHED AT my sister when he came to our home to evaluate her. When I reported him to his supervisor
column51: “That’s just [insert name of said jackass].”  He was one of the two caseworkers that contributed to the report I mentioned above
column52: which also included this:   So let me get this straight - I have to feed
column54: dress and help Edna in the bathroom and you can’t deduce whether or not she is able to vote? What in the fuck?! Now I realize I seem angry. And you can bet your balls I am. I’m also sad. Sad for those who don’t have family to stick up from them and who waste away God knows where
column55: monitored by no one. Or monitored by people who physically and sexually assault them.  I’m also sad for the caregivers who are SO EXHAUSTED - trying to take care of their loved ones - while also trying to take care of themselves and battling a system that is supposed to help
column56: but does nothing of the sort. And I know a lot of people give up. They let their dreams
column58: their friendships slide. All while trying not to resent the very person you’re doing it all for.  Edna wanted to sit next to me the other day while I was writing. Clearly
column59: she’s not impressed.  Here’s the thing: I REFUSE TO GIVE UP. I’M NOT GIVING UP ON HER OR MYSELF. I’m going to pursue my dreams while taking care of her
column60: AND while ensuring that the people paid to do their jobs ACTUALLY do them. That’s where you come in. I need you to help me get my story out there. Because I know I’m not alone in this. I want to connect with families who are in similar situations and also show people who have no idea what it’s like to care for someone with a disability (or even a loved one who is sick) that it can be rewarding. Super fucking hard. Exhausting. Painful. Isolating. But
column61: rewarding.  I’m going to get help for my sister - and others. My hope is that by sharing our story
column62: I can bring awareness to the lack of services and help for the disabled.  Thank you
column63: Jeanie  Facebook:  facebook.com/eisforedna Twitter: @EisforEdna   This made me cry  SIGNAL BOOST   STOP SCROLLING. THIS PERSON ISN’T ASKING FOR MONEY AND THIS POST WON’T MAKE YOU SAD. This is a really uplifting and inspirational story of a family sticking by each other and making things work despite a whole lot of shit They just want to find other people in the same position they are
column64: for a sense of community and to feel like they aren’t alone. I know out of all of you
column65: some of you have followers who are living with and taking care of intellectually or emotionally disabled family members
column66: and this lovely and unbreakable pair of sisters need to find them. SIGNAL BOOOOOOOOOST " False link
